Mr Truss-The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) NZ citizens who have been NZ residents for at least 10 years can use this NZ residence to meet minimum residence requirements for the following Australian benefits: Age Pension; Disability Support Pension; Parenting Payment-only sole parents (subject to a 6 month waiting period if they are not widowed)-and women whose partners receive age or disability support pensions. Australian Wife and Widow B Pensions are also covered under the agreement but these pensions can no longer be granted. (Note that the agreement is based on reside!1ce and not only NZ citizens are covered.) (2) (a) For the following Australian payments, NZ citizens must serve the same waiting period as other new arrivals (104 weeks): Special Benefit; Carer Payment; Widow Allowance; Youth Allowance; Austudy Payment. There is a 104 week waiting period for the following entitlements, but NZ citizens do not serve it: Partner Allowance; Mature Age Allowance; Sickness Allowance; Mobility Allowance; Seniors Health Card. There is a 104 week waiting period for Newstart Allowance but, under the terms of the social security agreement, NZ citizens currently only serve a 6 month waiting period. (2) (b) The 104 week waiting period for Partner, Mature Age, Sickness and Mobility Allowances and the Seniors Health Card applies only to new arrivals who have been issued with permanent visas. New Zealand citizens entering Australia are special category visa holders. (3) People from Pacific island nations (or from any other country) are covered by the social security agreement between Australia and New Zealand for early access to Age and Disability Support Pensions and Parenting Payment if they have had 10 years residence in NZ. The definition of residence in NZ does not include residence in the Cook Islands, Niue, Tokelau or any other Pacific nation. Pinochet, General Augusto (Question No. 55) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 November 1998: (1) Is it important after events of international significance regarding human rights for him or a representative of the Australian diplomatic corps to state the Commonwealth's view of the event; if not why not. (2) Following the arrest of the former dictator Chile, General Augusto Pinochet, in London on 17 October 1998, has (a) he, (b) the Australian High Commissioner to the UK or (c) a member of his Department expressed the Government's support to the British Government for the action it had taken; if not, why not. (3) Has (a) he, (b) the Australian Ambassador to Spain or (c) a member of his Department expressed the Government's support to the Spanish Government for the steps it is taking to bring General Pinochet to trial on charges of mass murder; if not, why not. (4) Has (a) he, (b) the Australian Ambassador to Chile or (c) a member of his Department expressed the Government's support of the steps the British and Spanish Governments have taken to bring General Pinochet to trial on charges of mass murder to the Chilean Government; if not, why not. (5) What is the Government's position on the arrest of General Pinochet and the attempt by the Spanish Government to extradite him to Spain to stand trial for the mass murder of Spanish citizens during his rule. (6) Does the Government support in principle a judicial inquiry by either the Spanish or Chilean Governments into General Pinochet's role in the disappearances and deaths of over 3000 persons in Chile between 1973 and 1990. Mr Downer-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows (1) The Australian Government regularly makes known its position regarding human rights, including its views on events of international significance. A recent example is the Parliamentary motion moved by the Prime Minister and passed by the House of Representatives on 10 December 1998 to mark the 50th Anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR), which reaffirmed Australia's enduring commitment to the principles enshrined in the UDHR. (2) (3) and (4) Following the arrest of Senator Pinochet, neither the Australian government nor its diplomatic representatives have made representations to the governments of Spain, the United Kingdom or Chile. The Australian Government believes that it would be inappropriate to comment on a matter that is being considered by the British legal system. (5) The Australian Government recognises that there were many serious human rights abuses in Chile during Senator Pinochet's Presidency. The Government is committed to the protection and promotion of human rights as an integral part of its foreign policy. However, the Australian Government accepts that the issue of whether Senator Pinochet should be extradited to Spain is for the relevant British authorities to decide. Senator of Pinochet's rights and obligations will be determined in accordance with existing arrangements under British and Spanish law. (6) The Australian Government is committed to the promotion and protection of human rights and welcomes efforts by other governments to advance these goals. The Australian Government recognises the right of the Spanish or any other government to seek extradition of persons alleged to have committed human rights abuses. The Australian Government also recognises the sovereign right of the Chilean people and Government to determine the most appropriate means of delivering and consolidating a transition to full democracy. The Australian Government does nol believe that it would be appropriate or helpful to comment on the means chosen by Chile to attain this goal. Mr Anderson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (a) Air safety incidents at or over Sydney (Kingsford Smith) airport since the east-west runway was re-opened [update from information provided to 3 May 1996]. Since 3 May 1996, BASI has received 718 safety incident reports involving air traffic at or over Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. - 538 of these were assessed as Category 5 occurrences. Category 5 occurrences are those which are primarily of statistical interest and are ed on the BASI database for future trend analysis. The information as reported to the Incident Bureau is available to the public on request. - 178 were assessed as Category 4 occurrences. Category 4 occurrences are those where the facts either; do not indicate a serious safety deficiency but the circumstances are sufficiently complex to require detailed information from the pilot, operator and/or other interested parties; or, some investigation is needed to expand and/or substantiate the initial information. Reports are available to the public on request. - 2 were assessed as Category 3 occurrences. Category 3 occurrences are those where the initial indications suggest potentially serious safety deficiencies. Consequently, an in-depth investigation is required to satisfy the concern for public safety. The report will include a Safety Action Statement detailing the relevant safety actions. Reports are available to the public on request. The first Category 3 incident occurred on 15 October 1997. A Boeing 747 aircraft (B747) arrived at Sydney 35 minutes prior to the end of the curfew. The aircraft was being operated in accordance with a concession which permitted arrival prior to the end Incidents of the curfew, subject to certain conditions. One of these conditions was that the aircraft should use only runway 34L for arrival. Enroute to Sydney and after passing the point at which the aircraft could divert to an alternate aerodrome with sufficient fuel remaining, a change in the wind direction, different to that which was forecast, passed through the Sydney area. This wind change made conditions on runway 34L operationally unacceptable to the crew of the aircraft. The crew elected to continue to Sydney and notitled air traffic services that they had a requirement to land prior to the end of the curfew as the aircraft had insufficient fuel to divert to an alternate aerodrome. The aircraft subsequently landed on runway 16R. The second Category 3 incident occurred on 22 July 1998 A Fairchild Industries Inc SA227-AC (Metro) aircraft landed on runway 34R, with an instruction to exit on taxiway Tango 1 and taxi via taxiway Juliet (for identification purposes, taxiways are named in accordance with the international phonetic alphabet). When approaching a mandatory holding point on taxiway Juliet, the pilot contacted the surface movement controller (SMC) and was instructed to taxi via taxiway Bravo and hold short recordof runway 25. This instruction was read back correctly by the pilot. Tower controllers subsequently observed the Metro taxiing along taxiway Juliet, past the entry to taxiway Bravo, towards runway 34L. At that time a Boeing 737 (B737) was touching down on runway 34L. The SMC instructed the pilot of the Metro to stop. As there was no reply the instruction was immediately repeated, and was subsequently acknowledged by the pilot. The Metro came to a stop at the edge of runway 34L. The pilot of the B737 was also instructed to stop immediately, but the aircraft was too close to the intersection of the runway with taxiway Juliet to comply. The pilot steered the B737 to the left of the runway centreline to increase its separation from the subsequently passing about 25 metres in front of that aircraft, at about 80 kts. At the time of the occurrence the weather was fine, there were no works taking place in the vicinity of the runway/taxiway intersection, and all relevant taxiway lights, runway holding point lights and movement area guidance signs were reported to have been functioning normally. The investigation is continuing. A copy of the final report can be sent to Mr MCClelland if required. (b) Occasions that the 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew have been breached since 3 May 1996. Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (Question No. 156) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998: Further to the answer to question No. 2618 (Hansard, 28 May 1998, page 4224), what was (a) his Department's and (b) Airservices Australia's response to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report published in January 1997 entitled 'An analysis of incidents involving air crew failing to comply with air traffic clearances: JuneAugust 1996.' Mr Anderson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: There were two recommendations arising from this report. Neither of the recommendations was directed specifically at the then Department of Transport and Regional Development: The following recommendation, reference R97001O, was issued to Airservices Australia on 31 January 1997 and stated: The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation recommends that Airservices Australia: 1. Review the current methods of flow control management with the aim of minimising the need for vectoring aircraft within the STAR environMetro, ment. (STAR-Standard Terminal Arrival Route). 2. Minimise the practice of instructing aircraft to resume a STAR once vectored off the STAR. 3. Ensure that SIDs and STARs, at all locations, are developed in accordance with consistent design principles. (SID-Standard Instrument Departure). 4. Maximise the use of ICAO standard radio phraseology in accordance with accepted worldwide practice. 5. Ensure that STAR design is compatible with aircraft FMS programs, especially for STARs which are not runway specific. (FMS-Flight Management System). The response to R970010 was received from Airservices Australia on 13 June 1997: 'I am writing to provide Airservices' response to Recommendation R970010 from the above report [An analysis of incidents involving air crew failing to comply with air traffic clearances: JuneAugust 1996]. Prior to the release of the report, Airservices' had been conducting independent reviews of many of the issues raised in your report. These reviews have included functional workshops in which BASI representatives have participated. The most recent workshop was convened for the purpose of discussing STARS, particularly in the Sydney environReport ment. As a result of these reviews, the following has occurred: 1. Airservices is currently progressing the development of an East Coast traffic management plan. The concept involves strategic and tactical planning to meter aircraft into Terminal areas and hence to place less reliance on vectoring in that airspace. 2. Prior to commencing any proposed vectoring, Air Traffic Control are required to advise the pilot of any expectation to resume the transition phase of a STAR. A requirement to rcsume a STAR can only be exercised during the transition phase. 3. Airservices STARS are designed in accordance with the Air Traffic Services STARS policy document which in turn states that they must be designed in accordance with ICAO specifications. The Operational Policy Branch of Air Traffic Services has undertaken a program to standardise STAR design locally and in the Asia-Pacific forum. 4. Phraseologies were the subject of a specific workshop in 1996 involving representation from the industry, CASA and the Australia Defence Force. This workshop recommended the adoption of ICAO standard phraseologies to the maximum extent possible. Where ICAO was silent on the issue the situation was to be resolved with international best practice, Australian specific phrases or plain language. Recommended phrascologies resulting from this forum have been incorporated into the AlP/MATS amendments effective 14 August 1997. 5. The Air Traffic Services STAR design document requires STARs to be developed in consultation with all users which includes ATS service providers and those flying the procedures. The intent of this consultation is to: ensure that operators are familiar with the development program; provide an opportunity for users to add value to STARs; determine pilot/operator acceptance; and ensure FMS compatibility where applicable. As part of the development process, STARS are "flown" in an approved airline simulator to confirm that the proposed STAR is both flyable, and acceptable for the aircraft type(s) used on that sector. This simulation normally includes FMS equipped operations. Airservices will continue to review the issues raised in your report to ensure the continued safety health of the Australian air traffic service system.' The following recommendation, reference R970011, was issued to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority on 31 January 1997 and stated: The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation recommends that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority require all international RPT AOC holders to include comprehensive route briefings in their General Operations Manual and require their aircrew to review comprehensive route briefing material prior to each flight to Australia. The response to R970011 was received from the Civil Aviation Safety Authority on 24 April 1997: "I refer to BASI Investigation Report "An Analysis of Incidents Involving Aircrew Failing to Comply with Air Traffic Clearances-June to August 1996: which incorporates Recommendation R970011. The recommendation is that CASA require all international RPT AOC holders to include comprehensive route briefings in their General Operations Manual and require their aircrew to review comprehensive route briefing material prior to each flight to Australia. Our response is as follows: Holders of international AOCs are required to comply with the provisions of the Civil Aviation Act, Regulations and Orders. Taken together, CAR 218 (Route qualifications of pilot in command of a regular public transport aircraft), CAR 233 (Responsibility of pilot in command before flight) and CAR 239 (Planning of flight by pilot in command) clearly require flight crews to be familiar with Australian procedures. It is also a condition of the AOC that operations be conducted in accordance with the requirements and procedures published in AlP. CASA does not believe that the analysis presented in the report justifies the implementation of recommendation R970011 at this time. Such a requirement would be difficult to police and is open to wide interpretation as to the acceptability of individual route briefings. We will monitor pilot briefing material during foreign operator ramp checks, and keep the situation under review. However, if the recommendations of R970010 are implemented by Airservices Australia, CASA believes that the incidence of failure to comply will markedly reduce.' BASI considers those recommendations 970010 and 97001] as being CLOSED-ACCEPTED, which means that the Bureau accepts the response without qualification. Civil Aviation Authority: Responsibility (Question No. 159) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998: Is the Civil Aviation Safety Authority responsible for reviewing the operation of the airline industry with respect to the safety of persons on the ground; if not, will he ensure that the responsibility is included in the authority's charter. Medicare Provider Numbers: Allocation (Question No. 199) Mr Andren asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 24 November 1998 : (1) Has his attention been drawn to a call by the NSW Farmers' Association for Medicare provider numbers to be allocated to match population numbers in specific geographic areas; if so, (a) what is the feasibility of the proposal and (b) will he introduce it. (2) Is it fact that existing incentives to attract medical practitioners to rural areas have failed

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: GPNR
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Government has acknowledged this and other health policies proposed by the NSW Farmers' Association including the proposal to link provider numbers to specific geographical areas as a mechanism to address the maldistribution of the medical workforce. There is a shortage of doctors particularly General Practitioners in rural and remote areas of Australia. While approximately 30% of Australia's population live outside capital cities and metropolitan areas, only 23% of General Practitioners work in rural and remote areas. Maldistribution of the medical workforce is not unique to Australia, in that it is a worldwide problem. The Government has carefully considered geographical control of provider numbers and believes that there are more effective means of addressing workforce maldistribution. Rather than force doctors to work in rural areas, it is preferable to provide incentives such as rural locum relief for rural practitioners. scholarships, the funding of regional clinical schools and the encouragement of rural students into medical schools. Research has shown that these students are more likely to return to rural areas upon completion of training. Furthermore, there may be constitutional barriers preventing the Commonwealth from taking such action - the Better Practice Program; Australia already produces enough medical graduates to meet the country's overall requirements and introduction of section 19AA of the Health Insurance Act (1973). known as the "provider number legislation", ensures a high standard of health care delivery by requiring all doctors to obtain postgraduate qualifications. The introduction of "area of need" access to Medicare rebates for temporary resident doctors and overseas-trained doctors has provided rural communities and public hospitals with an increased supply of medical practitioners and is an effective and longer-term solution for rural communities. (2) Existing incentives to attract medical practitioners to rural and remote areas have not failed. The General Practice Rural Incentives Program (GPRIP) which began in 1993 sought to improve the recruitment and retention of GPs in rural and remote communities. This program is now known as the Rural and Remote General Practice Program (RRGPP) and was devolved to Commonwealth funded Rural Workforce Agencies in July 1998. The GPRIP and now RRGPP programs have provided support to the rural and remote medical workforce and the communities they service in the following ways: - During the period 1992/93 to 1996/97 the overall number of GPs and 'other medical practitioners' practising in small rural centres in Australia grew by 7%, from 867 to 925; - The Continuous Medical Education/Locum Grants component demonstrated that the grants were well regarded as an effective mechanism to support rural and remote GPs and succeeded, in some states, in establishing locum support networks where previously none existed; and - Relocation grants as a mechanism to support rural doctors are available, with an increase from 50 to 113 grants approved during the period 1994/95-1996/97. Around 30% of those who received the funds say they would not have moved without it. Around 60-70% say that it helped and will make a difference to the length of time they stay. Retention is an important objective of this program and these support mechanisms for practising rural GPs. This objective has been met with available data demonstrating a reduction in drop out rates and an increase in medical practitioners entering rural and remote practice. Other rural incentives and support mechanisms are provided within the General Practice Strategy and include: - RACGP training program; - Rural Division Coordinating Units; and - the Rural Divisions of General Practice. In addition to this, the Government has sought to increase the training and supply, of Australian medical students via: - an increase in the level of rural health training for students of medicine within Australia. Coordination and support of this strategy is also recognised by many state and territory health departments. The University of Newcastle has demonstrated a commitment to this strategy through the introduction of a compulsory rural placement within their course structure; - the development of a clinical school at Wagga Wagga, New South Wales, for medical students undertaking training through the University of New South Wales. Through exposure to rural health care settings with appropriate levels of support, it is felt that this initiative will equip Australian medical graduates with both the skills and interest in working in rural areas; - the Commonwealth has agreed to provide funding to establish a medical school at the James Cook University, Townsville. The geographical location of this university offers an opportunity for medical students from rural or indigenous backgrounds or students wishing to gain experience in rural health, to undertake a clinical placement in a rural setting. The school will offer students appropriate levels of support during their placement, using clinical advisers and medical practitioners who possess skills and experience in rural health care; - the Government is supporting university initiatives to increase numbers of students from rural communities and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds in Medicine. This focus is particularly evident in the admission profile at the University of Newcastle, Monash University, The University of Queensland and The University of Tasmania. The Government recognises that medical students from rural or remote communities are more likely to return to these communities to practice medicine upon completion of their training when compared to students from urban backgrounds; - John Flynn Scholarships to provide medical students with rural experience during their undergraduate training; and - as part of its measures to enhance the training and experience of young doctors in their early postgraduate years, the Medical Training Review Panel (MTRP) has recommended that all doctors in their first two years post-graduation have at least one term of experience in a community setting. My department is working with the States and Territories to implement this recommendation. As many as possible of these rotations will be in rural areas. Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Racial Discrimination (Question No. 289) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 1998: (I) What progress has been made in (a) withdrawing or (b) modifying the declaration that Australia made on 30 September 1975 in ratifying the 1966 International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. (2) What other countries have made a similar Trust Committee declaration. (3) On what dates and in what terms did they in accordance make their declarations Mr Downer-The answer to the honourand able member's question is as follows: (1) On ratification of the International ConvenAct tion on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination on 30 September 1975, Australia made the following declaration: "The Government of Australia ....... declares that Australia is not at present in a position specifically to treat as offences all the matters covered by article 4(a) of the Convention. Acts of the kind there mentioned are punishable only to the extent provided by the existing criminal law dealing with such matters as the maintenance of public order, mischief, assault, riot, criminal libel, conspiracy and attempts. It is the intention of the Australian Government, at the first suitable moment, to seek from Parliament legislation specificalof ly implementing the terms of article 4 (a)." The declaration was last considered in 1995. Withdrawal of the declaration is not possible at this stage. Article 4 (a) of the Convention contemplates enactment of criminal offences for racial hatred and incitement to racial discrimination. As the of Racial Hatred Act 1995 contains only a civil prohibition on such conduct it does not fulfil Australia's obligations under Article 4 (a) and is not sufficient to allow Australia to withdraw its declaration. At this point only the ACT Discrimination Act 1991 makes serious racial and Herivilification a criminal offence. (2) I refer you to the UN Publication "Multilateral Treaties Deposited with the Secretary-General: status as at 31 December 1997". An updated of this publication is available on the internet: http://www.un.org/depts/treaty (3) See (2) above Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (Question No. 290) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 1998: (1) What progress has been made in (a) withdrawing or (b) modifying the reservations and declarations that Australia made on 13 August 1980 in ratifying the 1966 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. (2) What other countries have made similar reservations or declarations. (3) On what dates and in what terms did they make their reservations or declarations Mr Downer-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) When Australia lodged its instrument of ratification on 13 August, 1980, a number of declarations and reservations were lodged. On 6 November 1984 Australia withdrew the reservations and declarations made upon ratification with regard to Articles 2 and 50, 10, 14, 17, 19, 20 and 5 Australia has maintained the following reservations: Article 10 "In relation to paragraph 2 (a) the principle of segregation is accepted as an objective to be achieved progressively. In relation to paragraph 2(b) and 3 (second sentence) the obligation to segregate is accepted only to the extent that such segregation is considered by the responsible authorities to be beneficial to the juveniles or adults concerned." Article 14 "Australia makes the reservation that the provision of compensation for miscarriage of justice in the circumstances contemplated in paragraph 6 of article 14 may be by administrative procedures rather than pursuant to specific legal provision." Article 20 "Australia interprets the rights provided for by article 19, 21 and 22 as consistent with article 20; accordingly, the Commonwealth and the constituent States, having legislated with respect to the subject matter of the article in matters of practical concern in the interest of public order (ordre public), the right is reserved not to duce any further legislative provision on these matters." Declaration "Australia has a federal constitutional system in which legislative, executive and judicial powers are shared or distributed between the Commonwealth and the constituent States. The implementation of the treaty throughout Australia will be effected by the Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities having regard to their respective constitutional powers and arrangements concerning their exercise." The question of withdrawing or modifying the reservations made when Australia ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is considered every year when Australia's National Action Plan on human rights is updated. Paragraph (c) of the National Action Plan requires Australia to indicate human rights treaty reservations we intend to remove. In relation to the reservation to Articles 10 (2) and (3) of the Covenant, due to Australia's demographic and geographical features it is difficult to achieve the total segregration of accused and convicted prisoners, and children or juvenile prisoners from adult prisoners. Furthermore the Australian Government remains convinced that it is appropriate to allow the responsible authorities discretion to determine whether it is beneficial for a child or juvenile to be imprisoned with adults. However the Government is committed to achieving the goal of separation of accused and convicted prisoners and has taken some steps in this direction. For example, under the Standard Guidelines for Corrections in Australia, accused persons awaiting trial are separated from convicted persons as far as practicable and remandees are accorded different treatment from convicted persons. There are no present intentions to withdraw or modify Australia's reservations. In relation to the reservation to Article 14 of the Covenant, there are administrative procedures available in all Australian jurisdictions to provide compensation for miscarriages of justice in the circumstances envisaged in paragraph 6 of this Article. The reason for maintaining Australia's reservation to Article 14 was the requirement in paragraph 6 of that article for statutory compensation in cases of miscarriage of justice, whereas in Australia the procedures for granting compensation do not necessarily have a statutory basis. Accordingly, the reservation to Article 14 is still considered appropriate. The reservation to Article 20 retlects Australia's strong tradition of freedom of expression. Where there is a clear necessity to restrict that right in the public interest or for foreign policy reasons, the Federal Government will take the necessary introlegislative action. The Government has acted to prohibit or suppress propaganda in the past and has passed the Racial Hatred Act 1995. The Racial Hatred Act 1995 strikes a balance between the right to freedom of expression and rights of all persons to live free from fear of violence and racial hatred. Accordingly, there are no present intentions to withdraw Australia's reservation to Article 20. (2) I refer you to the UN Publication "Multilateral Treaties Deposited with the Secretary-General: status as at 31 December 1997". An updated version of this publication is available on the internet: http://www.un.org/depts/treaty (3) See (2) above.
